A Blackbox in the Car ?

American road planners are looking for a source of money to repair the declining highway system , and believe that they have found the solution in a small black box that can be found in the dashboard of each car .

The devices that record every kilometre drive and report the information to the authorities are at the heart of a controversial attempt by Washington and the state planning offices to revise the outdated system for financing US roads .
The normally rather boring area of road planning suddenly sparked an intense debate with colourful alliances .

Libertarians have allied themselves with environmental groups , arguing that the government can use the small boxes to record the kilometres – and possibly where they were driven – and then use the information to calculate tax modes .
The Tea Party is horrified .
The American Civil Rights Association ( ACLU ) is also deeply concerned and expresses a number of data protection concerns .
But , while Congress cannot agree on a course of action , several states are no longer waiting .
They are currently examining how to switch over the next ten years to a system where drivers pay per mile .
Thousands of drivers have already tested the tachographs , some of which are equipped with GPS monitoring .
This really is a must for our country .

“ It ’ s nothing that we may only use , ” said Hasan Ikhrata , Managing Director of Southern California Assn. of Governments , who plans to record the miles spent on all California federal drivers from 2025 .
The way we pay these taxes will change .
The technology is there .
The initiative comes at a time when the Highway Trust Fund , financed from taxes paid to Americans at the pump , is broken .
But in America , there is no longer as much tank as before .
Cars consume less petrol .
The state oil tax of 18.4 cents per gallon ( less than 4 cents per liter ) has not risen for 20 years .
Politicians , at high injection prices , do not dare to raise the tax even by a cent .
“ The petrol tax is simply not sustainable , ” says Lee Munnich , an expert in transport legislation at the University of Minnesota .
His state has recently equipped 500 cars with tachographs to test a milestone payment system .
“ This is the most sensible long-term alternative , ” he said .
bureaucrats call it a milestone user fee .

It is not surprising that the idea is coming up with urban liberals , because the tax could be used , for example , to influence driving behaviour in such a way as to reduce congestion and climate-damaging exhaust emissions .
California ’ s planners rely on the system to develop strategies to achieve the federal state ’ s ambitious , legally anchored goals on climate change .
But the Republican Bill Shuster from Pennsylvania , Chairman of the House Transportation Committee , has also said that he views it as the most viable long-term alternative .
The free marketers of the Reason Foundation are also inspired by the idea of letting drivers pay after a distance left behind .
“ This is not a tax that disappears in a black hole , ” explains Adrian Moore , Vice President of Directives at Reason .
People pay directly for what they get .
The movement is also supported by two former US transport ministers who , in a report in 2011 , called on Congress to move toward milestone accounting .
Last year , the US Senate approved a $ 90 million pilot project , covering 10,000 cars .

But the majority in the House of Representatives prevented the move , responding to the concerns of rural parliamentarians representing people who often have to spend many miles on their daily journey to work or to the city .
Several states and large cities , however , are moving in this direction on their own .
The most committed is Oregon , which currently attracts 5,000 drivers for the country ’ s largest experiment .
These drivers will soon pay mileage fees to the state instead of the petroleum tax .
Nevada has already completed a pilot project .
New York City is also considering such a thing .
Illinois is testing it to a limited extent with lorries .

And the I-95 coalition , which includes the transport ministries of 17 states on the east coast ( including Maryland , Pennsylvania , Virginia , and Florida ) , is currently examining how to introduce the change .
The concept is not a universal hit .
In Nevada , where 50 volunteers were recently equipped with the equipment , drivers were sceptical about the idea that the government could follow any of its movements .
“ Concerns about Big Brother and such things were a major problem , ” explains Alauddin Khan , Head of Strategy and Results Management at the Ministry of Transport in Nevada .
People did not want it .
When the test started , Nevada ’ s ACLU warned , “ It would be relatively easy to turn the tachograph into full-fledged monitoring devices . ”
There is no need to build a gigantic , bulky technological infrastructure that would inevitably be used to collect data on the daily movements of individuals .
Nevada belongs to a number of states that are now looking for affordable technology to capture the driving kilometres , but not exactly when and where .
So , Khan said , the public would also be more reassured .
The hunt for this technology has led some authorities to a small startup company called True Mileage in California .
The company originally did not intervene to help states tax drivers .
Rather , their aim was to take root in an emerging market for car insurance , where drivers should pay on the basis of the miles they have taken .
However , the equipment it tests is also interesting for road planners , because they do not work with GPS and provide only limited information that is regularly uploaded via modem .
“ People are more willing to participate if their speed and locations are not recorded , ” said Ryan Morrison , Managing Director of True Mileage .
Some of these public pilot programmes have made great mistakes .
There are much cheaper and less intrusive ways of doing this .
In Oregon , planners experiment with giving drivers a range of choices .
You can choose a device with or without GPS .
Or they do not choose any equipment at all and instead pay a flat rate based on the average miles travelled by all the inhabitants of the state .
Others hope to be able to sell the concept of a distrustful public by providing the equipment with more functions than minor ones .

In New York City , traffic officials want to develop a tax device that will also pay parking fees , pay insurance only for driving kilometres , and collect speed data from other vehicles in real time , allowing drivers to avoid congestion .

Esa Decisions Big Space Missions
Far planets , gravitational waves or black holes - European Space Agency experts must now agree on two major projects that they want to launch in the coming years .
30 proposals were available , five are still in the race .
Far worlds .
More than 1000 planets in other stars have already found astronomers .
No one knows whether there are at least some lives .
The choice is difficult : should you look for gravitational waves ?
Or rather explore the origin of the cosmos ?
Or are you looking for a memorable planet and perhaps discovering alien life ?
These questions are being asked by the European Space Agency Esa .
For their " Cosmic Vision " programme , they are looking for ideas for two major space projects , which are intended to significantly advance research .
The budget for such ' L-missions ' is approximately EUR 1 billion each .
The start is expected to be in 2028 and 2034 .
In early September , the elite of European space research met in Paris to discuss proposals for such missions .
30 ideas were under discussion , five of which have now come to the closer election .
Numerous bodies are examining the proposals , and the researchers are reviewing them .
In the next few days , a final decision will be taken by the scientific programme committee .
The Esa has selected four major questions to which the missions of the 2007 initiated Cosmic Vision programme will find answers .
What are the conditions for the emergence of planets and lives ?
The exact occurrences of stars originating from large gas clouds - and thus the emergence of planets that circle these stars - are still in proverbial darkness .
A large infrared telescope in space could penetrate this dark .
And if a star has a planet , under what circumstances can life arise there ?
To address this question , the space telescope " Cheops " is scheduled to start in 2017 , with a more detailed study of 500 already known planetary systems in our vicinity .
But the possibilities are limited , Cheops is a small mission with a budget of EUR 150 million .

With larger instruments , astronomers could depict fateful planets and even analyze the composition of their atmospheres , searching for " biomarkers " : gases that are considered an indication of biological activity .
How does the solar system work ?
This question , too , is ultimately intended to shed light on the conditions for the creation of life .
The magnetic activity of a star and the interaction of its magnetic field as well as the particle radiation that it emits with the planet system play an important role .
In our solar system these processes can be examined exemplary .
With the " Solar Orbiter " the Esa has already approved a M-class mission ( where the budget is around half a billion euros ) for this question .
The probe is scheduled to start in 2017 and observe the surface and activity of the sun closely .
Jupiter and his moons are also of great interest to the researchers .
They want to find out what role the giant planet played in the development of the solar system .
This is the first of the three L-missions of the Cosmic Vision program .
The probe " Juice " ( Jupiter Icy Moons Explorer ) is expected to begin its journey in 2022 .
Eight years later , she reached Jupiter to investigate the atmosphere of the planet and the icy moons of Europe , Kallisto and Ganymed .
What are the basic physical laws of the universe ?
The space offers many possibilities to study matter under extreme conditions and to examine whether the laws of nature we know are still valid there .
Perhaps deviations can also be found that could lead physicists to a new theory under which all known laws of nature can be combined .
How did the universe emerge and what is it ?
Our cosmos was created by the Big Bang 13.7 billion years ago .

In addition to the usual matter , consisting of stars , planets and creatures like us , there is dark matter whose gravity holds galaxies and galaxies together , and dark energy , through which the expansion of space accelerates .
So far , researchers have not known which physical laws were valid in the first fractions of the Big Bang , nor what dark matter and dark energy consist of .
With " Euclid " , the Esa has already approved an M mission , the launch of which is scheduled for 2020 .

With a special telescope , the probe is intended to investigate the distribution of matter in the universe for the first time in the entire sky , thus enabling conclusions on the nature of dark matter and dark energy .
Who Would Go the Race
Of the 30 proposals , only two will remain at the end of the selection process .
In the opinion of many experts , the best chances of an L-mission is " E-Lisa " , a sophisticated concept for detecting gravitational waves .
Physicists understand changes in the structure of space time that Albert Einstein predicted almost 100 years ago .
They have not yet been proven .
Elisa could do that , hoping the scientists behind the project .
The mission provides for a detector made up of two or three probes , stationed in space .
In contrast to plants on Earth , it could also prove gravitational waves created during the Big Bang , providing new insights into the emergence of the cosmos .

Four other proposals compete for the second L-mission : a large X-ray telescope called " Athena " , which is to explore black holes , " Icy Planets " , another mission on the outer planets of the solar system , " Prism " , a mission to measure the cosmic background radiation , and the " Exoplanet Finder " , which is supposed to detect and investigate fanciful planets .
